text: rWBclimate R interface World Bank climate data used World Bank climate knowledge portal.
Right now package installable github devtools:

rWBclimate provides access three different classes climate data two different spatial scales. three different classes data GCM model , ensemble historical data. data class let download two different four different types two different variables. two variables either precipitation expressed millimeters temperature degrees celcius, variable can download data one four types. data fully described along examples.

Model data Almost model data Climate Data API derived 15 global circulation models (GCMs) used Intergovernmental Panel Climate Change (IPCC) 4th Assessment Reports. models simulate response global climate system increasing greenhouse gas concentrations. data Climate Data API aggregated country basin levels, explained . Note data modeled estimates temperature precipitation changes different time periods different GCMs scenarios. include changes future time periods also “backcasting” (model representations past) set past time periods. latter confused instrumental observed data. specific dataset historical measured climate data well. Data types Data time scales Climate model data available averages 20 year chunks. package automatically convert start end data valid API calls return data given start end date. following time periods available Data spatial scales Data available two spatial scales. first country level. can download data country world using valid ISO 3 letter country code. Alternatively can download data basin network slightly higher resolution represented number 1-468. based level 2 boundaries waterbase.org, can view full map available basins. Downloading GCM Model Data Model data downloaded two different scenarios, A2 B1. Generally A2 scenarios little difference future now B1 ecologically friendly world greater decrease emissions. A2 B1 downloaded 15 different GCM models listed table : model data can downloaded two main functions: Example 1: Plotting monthly data different GCM’s Say want compare temperature two different models USA see vary. can download data USA subset specific models ’re interested plot . plot chunk getmodeldata Subsetting data can bit tedious. also compare models just one scenario, A2. plot chunk plotallmodeldata Example 2: Plotting annual data different countries Data can extracted countries basins submitted vectors. plot expected temperature anomaly 20 year period baseline control period 1961-2000. countries chosen span north south pole. ’s clear plot northern countries (US Canada) biggest anomaly, Belize, equatorial country, smallest anomaly. plot chunk annualdata Downloading Ensemble Model Data Getting raw model data really useful comparing scenarios different GCM’s. However many users might interested aggregated measurements. can download ensemble climate data. give access 15 GCM’s combined queries return 10th, 50th 90th quantiles ensemble GCM’s. queries constructed raw model data data types, spatial scales time scales. Example 1: Comparing model quantiles Let’s look monthly precipitation predictions Indonesia period 2080-2100. ’ll create plot precipitation expected future two different scenarios plot different colours dashed lines indicate quantiles. plot chunk comparing quantiles Example 2: Ensemble statistics can also download 13 different ensemble statistics basins countries aside raw data . derived statistics often given relative control period, 1961-2000. time periods however 2046-2065, 2081-2100, standard 20 year intervals available raw model data. full table available statistics. Similar previous example looked temperature anomaly along latitudinal gradient, can examine complex ensemble statistics. examine average minimum daily temperature Scavavadian countries. Also given two time periods available, need enter specific year range plot chunk enesmble data Downloading Historical Data possible extract historical data GCM queries, acutally model backcasting output, true historical records. climate data api can download data spatial scales requests (country basin), time scale differs. can download data monthly, yearly decadanal time scales. Monthly data actually mean monthly temperature precipitation value month 1901-2009 countries, 1960-2009 basins. can indicate type data want call setting time_scale parameter month,year decade. Example 1: Downloading monthly data can download historical precipitation Belize, Colombia, Peru Bolivia. plot chunk historicalmonth Example 2: Downloading annual data Another use historical data look increases temperature time. plot chunk historicalyear Mapping climate Data Data can mapped ggplot2 downloading KML files climate database, creating dataframes plotting using ggplot2. Maps available basin country spatial scale. KML files can large files downloaded locally cached directory must set using kmlpath option. can set directory follows: options(kmlpath = <yourpath>). KML files stored downloaded aren’t found locally. wish get rid , need manually delete . rWBclimate allows download maps plot ggplot maps, can automatically create maps climate data. convenience ’ve created basin country vectors six continents (Antartica data database). data files automatically loaded package can accessed basins NoAm_basin, SoAm_basin,Asia_basin,Eur_basin,Africa_basin,Oceana_basin. Countries can similarly accessed NoAm_country, SoAm_country,Asia_country,Eur_country,Africa_country,Oceana_country. plotting continent, can take time first download KML files. Example 1: Creating map dataframe plotting Creating map data frames straightforward, simply provide list valid country codes function create_map_df plot chunk map_plot Example 2: Mapping climate data order map climate data need single point data spatial polygon(country basin) map dataframe. ’ve already created Africa basin map dataframe, now need get data basin. Now map dataframe data can bind together function climate_map(). function two options, can return ggplot2 map can return dataframe can plot easily ggplot2. useful means bind together multiple dataframes bigger plots, perhaps add new data plot chunk climatemap Example 3: Creating temperature map world plot chunk worldmap

title: A package for accessing World Bank climate data
text: rWBclimate provides access three different classes climate data two different spatial scales. three different classes data GCM model , ensemble historical data. data class let download two different four different types two different variables. two variables either precipitation expressed millimeters temperature degrees celcius, variable can download data one four types. data fully described along examples.

title: A package for accessing World Bank climate data
text: Model data Almost model data Climate Data API derived 15 global circulation models (GCMs) used Intergovernmental Panel Climate Change (IPCC) 4th Assessment Reports. models simulate response global climate system increasing greenhouse gas concentrations. data Climate Data API aggregated country basin levels, explained . Note data modeled estimates temperature precipitation changes different time periods different GCMs scenarios. include changes future time periods also “backcasting” (model representations past) set past time periods. latter confused instrumental observed data. specific dataset historical measured climate data well. Data types Data time scales Climate model data available averages 20 year chunks. package automatically convert start end data valid API calls return data given start end date. following time periods available Data spatial scales Data available two spatial scales. first country level. can download data country world using valid ISO 3 letter country code. Alternatively can download data basin network slightly higher resolution represented number 1-468. based level 2 boundaries waterbase.org, can view full map available basins. Downloading GCM Model Data Model data downloaded two different scenarios, A2 B1. Generally A2 scenarios little difference future now B1 ecologically friendly world greater decrease emissions. A2 B1 downloaded 15 different GCM models listed table : model data can downloaded two main functions: Example 1: Plotting monthly data different GCM’s Say want compare temperature two different models USA see vary. can download data USA subset specific models ’re interested plot . plot chunk getmodeldata Subsetting data can bit tedious. also compare models just one scenario, A2. plot chunk plotallmodeldata Example 2: Plotting annual data different countries Data can extracted countries basins submitted vectors. plot expected temperature anomaly 20 year period baseline control period 1961-2000. countries chosen span north south pole. ’s clear plot northern countries (US Canada) biggest anomaly, Belize, equatorial country, smallest anomaly. plot chunk annualdata Downloading Ensemble Model Data Getting raw model data really useful comparing scenarios different GCM’s. However many users might interested aggregated measurements. can download ensemble climate data. give access 15 GCM’s combined queries return 10th, 50th 90th quantiles ensemble GCM’s. queries constructed raw model data data types, spatial scales time scales. Example 1: Comparing model quantiles Let’s look monthly precipitation predictions Indonesia period 2080-2100. ’ll create plot precipitation expected future two different scenarios plot different colours dashed lines indicate quantiles. plot chunk comparing quantiles Example 2: Ensemble statistics can also download 13 different ensemble statistics basins countries aside raw data . derived statistics often given relative control period, 1961-2000. time periods however 2046-2065, 2081-2100, standard 20 year intervals available raw model data. full table available statistics. Similar previous example looked temperature anomaly along latitudinal gradient, can examine complex ensemble statistics. examine average minimum daily temperature Scavavadian countries. Also given two time periods available, need enter specific year range plot chunk enesmble data Downloading Historical Data possible extract historical data GCM queries, acutally model backcasting output, true historical records. climate data api can download data spatial scales requests (country basin), time scale differs. can download data monthly, yearly decadanal time scales. Monthly data actually mean monthly temperature precipitation value month 1901-2009 countries, 1960-2009 basins. can indicate type data want call setting time_scale parameter month,year decade. Example 1: Downloading monthly data can download historical precipitation Belize, Colombia, Peru Bolivia. plot chunk historicalmonth Example 2: Downloading annual data Another use historical data look increases temperature time. plot chunk historicalyear Mapping climate Data Data can mapped ggplot2 downloading KML files climate database, creating dataframes plotting using ggplot2. Maps available basin country spatial scale. KML files can large files downloaded locally cached directory must set using kmlpath option. can set directory follows: options(kmlpath = <yourpath>). KML files stored downloaded aren’t found locally. wish get rid , need manually delete . rWBclimate allows download maps plot ggplot maps, can automatically create maps climate data. convenience ’ve created basin country vectors six continents (Antartica data database). data files automatically loaded package can accessed basins NoAm_basin, SoAm_basin,Asia_basin,Eur_basin,Africa_basin,Oceana_basin. Countries can similarly accessed NoAm_country, SoAm_country,Asia_country,Eur_country,Africa_country,Oceana_country. plotting continent, can take time first download KML files. Example 1: Creating map dataframe plotting Creating map data frames straightforward, simply provide list valid country codes function create_map_df plot chunk map_plot Example 2: Mapping climate data order map climate data need single point data spatial polygon(country basin) map dataframe. ’ve already created Africa basin map dataframe, now need get data basin. Now map dataframe data can bind together function climate_map(). function two options, can return ggplot2 map can return dataframe can plot easily ggplot2. useful means bind together multiple dataframes bigger plots, perhaps add new data plot chunk climatemap Example 3: Creating temperature map world plot chunk worldmap cite package ‘rWBclimate’ publications use:
code:
get_model_temp()  ## Get model temperature data get_model_precip() ## Get model precipitation data usa.dat <- get_model_temp("USA", "mavg", 2080, 2100) usa.dat.bcc <- usa.dat[usa.dat$gcm == "bccr_bcm2_0", ] usa.dat.had <- usa.dat[usa.dat$gcm == "ukmo_hadcm3", ] ## Add a unique ID to each for easier plotting usa.dat.bcc$ID <- paste(usa.dat.bcc$scenario, usa.dat.bcc$gcm, sep = "-") usa.dat.had$ID <- paste(usa.dat.had$scenario, usa.dat.had$gcm, sep = "-") plot.df <- rbind(usa.dat.bcc, usa.dat.had) ggplot(plot.df, aes(x = as.factor(month), y = data, group = ID, colour = gcm,     linetype = scenario)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Average temperature in degrees C 
 between 2080 and 2100") +     xlab("Month") + theme_bw() ggplot(usa.dat[usa.dat$scenario == "a2", ], aes(x = month, y = data, group = gcm,     colour = gcm)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Average temperature in degrees C 
 between 2080 and 2100") +     xlab("Month") + theme_bw() country.list <- c("CAN", "USA", "MEX", "BLZ", "COL", "PER", "BOL", "ARG") country.dat <- get_model_temp(country.list, "annualanom", 2010, 2100) # Subset data country.dat.bcc <- country.dat[country.dat$gcm == "bccr_bcm2_0", ] ## Exclude A2 scenario country.dat.bcc <- subset(country.dat.bcc, country.dat.bcc$scenario != "a2") ggplot(country.dat.bcc, aes(x = fromYear, y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) +     geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Temperature anomaly over baseline") +     theme_bw() idn.dat <- get_ensemble_precip("IDN", "mavg", 2080, 2100) # Set line types ltype <- rep(1, dim(idn.dat)[1]) ltype[idn.dat$percentile != 50] <- 2 idn.dat$ltype <- ltype # Create uniqueIDs idn.dat$uid <- paste(idn.dat$scenario, idn.dat$percentile, sep = "-") ggplot(idn.dat, aes(x = as.factor(month), y = data, group = uid, colour = scenario,     linetype = as.factor(ltype))) + geom_point() + geom_path() + xlab("Month") +     ylab("Rain in mm") + theme_bw() country.list <- c("ISL", "FIN", "NOR", "SWE") country.dat <- get_ensemble_stats(country.list, "mavg", "tmin_means") ####### Subset data Exclude A2 scenario country.dat.b1 <- subset(country.dat, country.dat$scenario == "b1") # choose just one percentile country.dat.b1 <- subset(country.dat.b1, country.dat.b1$percentile == 50) # get just one year period country.dat.b1 <- subset(country.dat.b1, country.dat.b1$fromYear == 2081)   ggplot(country.dat.b1, aes(x = month, y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) +     geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Average daily minimum temperature") +     theme_bw() + xlab("Month") country.list <- c("BLZ", "COL", "PER", "BOL") country.dat <- get_historical_precip(country.list, "month")  ggplot(country.dat, aes(x = month, y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) +     geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Average historical precipitation (mm)") +     theme_bw() + xlab("Month") country.list <- c("USA", "MEX", "CAN", "BLZ") country.dat <- get_historical_temp(country.list, "year")  ggplot(country.dat, aes(x = year, y = data, group = locator)) + geom_point() +     geom_path() + ylab("Average annual temperature of Canada") + theme_bw() +     xlab("Year") + stat_smooth(se = F, colour = "black") + facet_wrap(~locator,     scale = "free") # Set the kmlpath option options(kmlpath = "~/kmltemp") ## Here we use a list basins for Africa af_basin <- create_map_df(Africa_basin) ggplot(af_basin, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group)) + geom_polygon() + theme_bw() af_basin_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(Africa_basin, "annualanom", 2080, 2100) ## Subset data to just one scenario, and one percentile af_basin_dat <- subset(af_basin_dat, af_basin_dat$scenario == "a2") af_basin_dat <- subset(af_basin_dat, af_basin_dat$percentile == 50) af_map <- climate_map(af_basin, af_basin_dat, return_map = T) af_map + scale_fill_continuous("Temperature 
 anomaly", low = "yellow", high = "red") +     theme_bw() options(kmlpath = "~/kmltemp") ### Combine all country vectors  world <- c(NoAm_country, SoAm_country, Eur_country, Asia_country, Africa_country,     Oceana_country) world_map_df <- create_map_df(world) world_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(world, "annualavg", 2080, 2100) ## Subset data to just one scenario, and one percentile world_dat <- subset(world_dat, world_dat$scenario == "a2") world_dat <- subset(world_dat, world_dat$percentile == 50)  world_map <- climate_map(world_map_df, world_dat, return_map = T) world_map + scale_fill_continuous("Temperature 
 at 2100", low = "yellow",     high = "red") + theme_bw() Edmund Hart (). rWBclimate: A package for accessing World Bank climate data. R package version 0.1.3   http://github.com/ropensci/rWBclimate  A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is    @Manual{,     title = {rWBclimate: A package for accessing World Bank climate data},     author = {Edmund Hart},     note = {R package version 0.1.3},     url = {http://github.com/ropensci/rWBclimate},   }

title: Map climate data — climate_map
text: Create maps climate data.  requires two data inputs, map dataframe, climate dataframe.  climate data must one data point per spatial mapping point,e.g. 1 data point per country basin mapped.

title: Map climate data — climate_map
text: map_df map dataframe generated create_map_df() data_df climate dataframe one piece data mapped unique spatial polygon. return_map True returns ggplot2 object, False returns dataframe data items matched polygon can plot later .

title: Map climate data — climate_map
text: Either ggplot2 map dataframe depending parameter return_map

title: Map climate data — climate_map
code: if (FALSE) { #Set the kmlpath option options(kmlpath = "~/kmltemp2") ##Here we use a list basins for Africa af_basin <- create_map_df(Africa_basin) af_basin_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(Africa_basin,"annualanom",2080,2100) ##  Subset data to just one scenario, and one percentile af_basin_dat <- subset(af_basin_dat,af_basin_dat$scenario == "a2") af_basin_dat <- subset(af_basin_dat,af_basin_dat$percentile == 50) af_map <- climate_map(map_df = af_basin, data_df = af_basin_dat, return_map = TRUE) af_map + scale_fill_continuous("Temperature \n anomaly",low="yellow",high = "red") + theme_bw()  }

title: Download ensemble precipitation data — get_ensemble_precip

title: Download ensemble precipitation data — get_ensemble_precip
text: locator vector either watershed basin ID's http://data.worldbank.org/sites/default/files/climate_data_api_basins.pdf can just single basin id, vector ids.  ids strings. type type data retrieve, must "mavg" monthly averages, "annualavg" annual averages, "manom" monthly anomaly, "annualanom"  annual anomaly. start start year gather data . end end year gather data .

title: Download ensemble precipitation data — get_ensemble_precip

title: Download ensemble precipitation data — get_ensemble_precip
code: if (FALSE) { # Get data for 2 basins, annual average precipitation for all valid time periods # then subset them, and plot precip_dat <- get_ensemble_precip(c("2","231"),"annualavg",1900,3000) precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$scenario!="b1") precip_dat$uniqueGroup <- paste(precip_dat$percentile,precip_dat$locator,sep="-") ggplot(precip_dat,aes(x=fromYear,y=annualVal,group=uniqueGroup,colour=as.factor(locator), linetype=as.factor(percentile)))+ geom_path()  ### Get data for 2 countries with monthly precipitation values precip_dat <- get_ensemble_precip(c("USA","BRA"),"mavg",2020,2030) precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$scenario!="b1") precip_dat$uniqueGroup <- paste(precip_dat$percentile,precip_dat$locator,sep="-") ggplot(precip_dat,aes(x=as.factor(month),y=monthVals,group=uniqueGroup, colour=locator))+geom_path() }

title: Download ensemble statistics — get_ensemble_stats
text: Statistics can either two time periods: 2046 - 2065 2081 - 2100 given units relative control period:  1961 - 2000.  Derived statistics can following:

title: Download ensemble statistics — get_ensemble_stats
text: locator ISO3 country code want data . (http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49alpha.htm) basin ID [1-468] type type data want "mavg" monthly averages, "annualavg" stat statistics interest, must one ones listed .

title: Download ensemble statistics — get_ensemble_stats
code: if (FALSE) {  ### Request data on the US for days of rain over 2 mm  ens_dat <- get_ensemble_stats("USA","mavg","ppt_days2")  # subset to the 50th percentile and just until the year 2100  ens_dat <- subset(ens_dat, ens_dat$percentile == 50)  ens_dat <- subset(ens_dat,ens_dat$toYear == 2100)  ggplot(ens_dat,aes(x = as.factor(month), y= monthVals, group=scenario,   colour=scenario)) + geom_point() + geom_line() }

title: Download ensemble temperature data — get_ensemble_temp
text: Function wraps get_ensemble_climate_data returns precipitation basin country mm.  Output 10th 50th 90th percentile gcm's a1 b2 scenarios.

title: Download ensemble temperature data — get_ensemble_temp
text: locator vector either watershed basin ID's http://data.worldbank.org/sites/default/files/climate_data_api_basins.pdf can just single basin id, vector ids.  ids strings. type type data retrieve, must "mavg" monthly averages, "annualavg" annual averages, "manom" monthly anomaly, "annualanom" annual anomaly. start start year gather data . end end year gather data .

title: Download ensemble temperature data — get_ensemble_temp
text: dataframe precipitation predictions mm scenarios, gcms, time period.

title: Download ensemble temperature data — get_ensemble_temp
text: start end year can years, years coerced periods outlined API (http://data.worldbank.org/developers/climate-data-api) anomaly periods valid future scenarios based reference period 1969 - 1999, see API full details.

title: Download ensemble temperature data — get_ensemble_temp
code: if (FALSE) { # Get data for 2 basins, annual average precipitation for all valid time periods # then subset them, and plot temp_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(locator=c(2,231), type="annualavg", start=1900, end=3000) temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$scenario!="b1") temp_dat$uniqueGroup <- paste(temp_dat$percentile,temp_dat$locator,sep="-") ggplot(temp_dat, aes(x=fromYear, y=data, group=uniqueGroup,        colour=as.factor(locator), linetype=as.factor(percentile))) +    geom_path()  ### Get data for 2 countries with monthly precipitation values temp_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(locator = c("USA","BRA"), type = "mavg", start = 2020, end = 2030) temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$scenario!="b1") temp_dat$uniqueGroup <- paste(temp_dat$percentile, temp_dat$locator,sep="-") ggplot(temp_dat, aes(x=as.factor(month), y=data, group=uniqueGroup, colour=locator)) +    geom_path() }

title: Download historical climate data — get_historical_data
text: Climate Data API provides access historical temperature precipitation data. data separate outputs GCMs, based gridded climatologies Climate Research Unit.

title: Download historical climate data — get_historical_data
text: locator ISO3 country code want data . (http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49alpha.htm) basin ID [1-468]. historical period country 1901 - 2009, 1960 - 2009 basin cvar climate variable interested . "pr" precipitation, "tas" temperature celcius. time_scale time scale want return values .  Must "month", "year" "decade"

title: Download historical climate data — get_historical_data
text: dataframe historical climate data

title: Download historical climate data — get_historical_data
text: time_scale parameter returns different number variables depending input timescale. Month return 12 values, historical average month across years.  Year return yearly averages year, decade return decade averages.

title: Download historical precipitation data — get_historical_precip
text: historical period country 1901 - 2009, 1960 - 2009 basin. time_scale parameter returns different number variables depending input timescale. Month return 12 values, historical average month across years.  Year return yearly averages year, decade return decade averages.

title: Download historical precipitation data — get_historical_precip
code: if (FALSE) { ## Plot annual historical data for USA, Brazil and Australia hist_dat <- get_historical_precip(c("USA","BRA","AUS"),"year") ggplot(hist_dat,aes(x = year,y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Mean annual precipitaion")  ## Plot monthly historical data hist_mo_dat <- get_historical_precip(c("USA","AUS","BRA","IDN"),time_scale="month") ggplot(hist_mo_dat,aes(x = month,y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Mean monthly precipitaion")  }

code: if (FALSE) { ## Plot annual historical data for USA, Brazil and Australia hist_dat <- get_historical_precip(c("USA","BRA","AUS"),"year") ggplot(hist_dat,aes(x = year,y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Mean annual temperature")  ## Plot monthly historical data hist_mo_dat <- get_historical_precip(c("USA","AUS","BRA","IDN"),time_scale="month") ggplot(hist_mo_dat,aes(x = month,y = data, group = locator, colour = locator)) + geom_point() + geom_path() + ylab("Mean monthly temperature")  }

title: Download GCM precipitation data — get_model_precip

title: Download GCM precipitation data — get_model_precip
text: locator vector either watershed basin ID's http://data.worldbank.org/sites/default/files/climate_data_api_basins.pdf can just single basin id, vector ids.  ids strings. type type data retrieve, must "mavg" monthly averages, "annualavg" annual averages, "manom" monthly anomaly, "annualanom"  annual anomaly. start start year gather data . end end year gather data .

title: Download GCM precipitation data — get_model_precip

title: Download GCM precipitation data — get_model_precip
text: start end year can years, years coerced         periods outlined API (http://data.worldbank.org/developers/climate  -data-api)         anomaly periods valid future scenarios based          reference period 1969 - 1999, see API full details.

title: Download GCM precipitation data — get_model_precip
code: if (FALSE) { # Get data for 2 basins, annual average precipitation for all valid time periods # then subset them, and plot precip_dat <- get_model_precip(c("2","231"),"annualavg",1900,3000) precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$gcm=="ukmo_hadcm3") precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$scenario!="b1") ggplot(precip_dat,aes(x=fromYear,y=annualData,group=locator,colour=locator))+geom_path()  ### Get data for 4 countries with monthly precipitation values precip_dat <- get_model_precip(c("USA","BRA","CAN","YEM"),"mavg",2020,2030) precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$gcm=="ukmo_hadcm3") precip_dat <- subset(precip_dat,precip_dat$scenario!="b1") ggplot(precip_dat,aes(x=as.factor(month),y=monthVals,group=locator,colour=locator))+geom_path() }

title: Download GCM temperature data — get_model_temp
code: if (FALSE) { # Get data for 2 basins, annual average temperature for all valid time periods # then subset them, and plot temp_dat <- get_model_temp(c("2","231"),"annualavg",1900,3000) temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$gcm=="ukmo_hadcm3") temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$scenario!="b1") ggplot(temp_dat,aes(x=fromYear,y=data,group=locator, colour=locator))+geom_path()  ### Get data for 4 countries with monthly tempitation values temp_dat <- get_model_temp(c("USA","BRA","CAN","YEM"),"mavg",2020,2030) temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$gcm=="ukmo_hadcm3") temp_dat <- subset(temp_dat,temp_dat$scenario!="b1") ggplot(temp_dat,aes(x=as.factor(month),y=data,group=locator, colour=locator))+geom_path() }

title: Convert kml to polygon — kml_to_sp
text: Create sp SpatialPolygon SpatialPolygonDataFrame object downloaded KML file data file

title: Convert kml to polygon — kml_to_sp
text: map_df map dataframe generated create_map_df() df climate dataframe one piece data mapped unique spatial polygon. crs_string Coordinate reference string use spatial projection.  Default WSGS84.

title: Convert kml to polygon — kml_to_sp
text: SpatialPolygon object

title: Convert kml to polygon — kml_to_sp
text: dataframe included, spatial polygon dataframe object created.  dataframe must one unique piece information per polygon, otherwise error thrown.  However just basic spatial polygon created dataframe included.

title: Convert kml to polygon — kml_to_sp
code: if (FALSE) { sa_map <- create_map_df(locator=SoAm_country) sa_dat <- get_ensemble_temp(SoAm_country,"annualanom",2080,2100) sa_dat <- subset(sa_dat,sa_dat$scenario == "a2") sa_dat <- subset(sa_dat,sa_dat$percentile == 50) sa_poly <- kml_to_sp(sa_map,df = sa_dat) ### colors are a bit off, but just to verify that data is  spplot(sa_poly,"data")  }

title: rWBclimate — rWBclimate
text: rWBclimate
